dominant_strategy: Rigid fill-in-the-blank template with minimal adaptation; student cycles between two sentence frames regardless of word type or grammatical fit.
template_types: I am hapy [TARGET] day., The [TARGET] is fun.
anomalous_responses: Target: 'because' | Sentence: 'I am hapy because day.' (semantic nonsense; preposition used as noun), Target: 'quickly' | Sentence: 'I am hapy quickly day.' (adverb forced into noun position)
clinical_interpretation: This student demonstrates severe difficulty with sentence generation and vocabulary integration. The pervasive misspelling ('hapy'), grammatically incoherent constructions ('I am hapy [adjective/noun/adverb] day'), and complete reliance on two fixed templates suggest either limited English proficiency, low phonemic awareness, insufficient understanding of parts of speech, or significant test anxiety/task avoidance.

dominant_strategy: Meta-linguistic avoidance: Student writes about using the word correctly rather than demonstrating contextual use

The student demonstrates awareness that words have correct uses but does not demonstrate actual vocabulary knowledge through application.

The pattern suggests either significant receptive vocabulary gaps, test anxiety leading to avoidance behavior, or possible limited English proficiency masking actual word knowledge.
